thermal performance, simulations and toxicological assessment

a b s t r a c t
The paper presents the results of an experimental activity aimed at producing and characterizing a nanoencapsulated PEG600 (PCMs) into a silica shell. The nano-encapsulation was meant to be useful to improve the material’s suitability to integration in building components. The (300 ± 15) nm nanoparticles that were produced underwent a full characterization of their thermal performances. An enthalpy of fusion as high as 66.24 kJ/kg, in a tight melting temperature range (20–21 °C) was obtained, making the material suitable for thermal energy storage in buildings. In order to demonstrate the benefits of such as this technology on the reduction of heating and cooling demand of buildings, a concentration of 50% in weight of nanoparticles was, then, embedded into a gypsum plasterboard and used for all indoor plastered surfaces of a reference residential buildings. A saving of respectively up to 4.3% and up to 1.1% of heating and cooling energy demand was predicted in comparison to the ones of a building without PCM. Finally, the material underwent a full toxicological characterization exposing human alveolar basal epithelial cells to nanoparticles. The results showed that there were no toxic effects on cell morphology.

. Introduction
In the last decade, the potential integration of PCMs in building omponents, as suitable latent thermal energy storage systems, has ecome a goal for several research activities. PCMs can store large mounts of latent heat in their phase transitions [1] , achieving sigificant energy savings and comfort in buildings. If, on the one and, sensible heat refers to heat that can be sensed by means of
thermometer, latent heat storage refers to the undetectable heat ransfer, intrinsically associated with a phase transition [2] . PCMs an utilise their high latent heat storage, corresponding to the umber of chemical bonds to be broken to activate the full isother-
al phase transition at constant pressure. For this reason, within he tight temperature range in which the phase transition occurs, CMs show higher efficiency than any other sensible heat storage
aterial [3] . PCMs are classified in three classes: organic, inorganic nd eutectic [3] : organic PCMs are paraffins, fatty acids, esters, and lcohols [4] while the most used inorganic PCMs are salt hydrates.

Genrally, higher melting temperatures are reported for metals and norganic PCMs, whereas they are lower in organic, salt hydrate nd eutectic PCMs [5] . The main figures of merit affecting PCMs ffectiveness are the melting temperature, the amount of latent eat of transition per unit weight, thermal conductivity ( λ) and he specific heat. Shape-stabilized PCMs, by means of micro- and
ano-encapsulation processes, avoid any leakage risk in the liquid hase, but also maximize heat transfer due to larger available sur-
ace area, compared to macrocapsules [6] . Micro-encapluation is a echnology to encapsulate and shape-stabilize PCMs in spheres at
icroscale range ( > 1 μm); the current research trend is aimed at educing the encapsulation size within the nanoscale range, so as o maximize size effects and surface area involved in heat transfer 7] .
PCMs can help customizing the redistribution of thermal loads n buildings. A recent review showed that generally PCMs are em-
edded in building elements and materials, especially in walls and oor elements, because they can provide energy storage by means f latent heat accumulation, resulting in higher heating storage

The improvement observed in PCM-embodying elements is due to this enhanced latent heating storage, even if no variation of specific heats takes place. For instance, the application of PCM capsules with paraffinic wax in lime plaster enhanced the apparent specific heat capacity, compared to the reference material [9] . PCM-enhanced plasters have been investigated as a suitable chance in the refurbishment of building envelopes, in the Mediterranean climate [10] , in the hypothesis of adopting 3.0 cm thick plaster on all exposures and in different climatic conditions. The heat storage capacity of a special composite plaster was compared to a commercially produced lime-cement mortar, reporting an increase from 0.4 kJ/(kg ·K) to about 2.1 kJ/(kg ·K) after the addition of 24% PCM [11] . Pavlick et al. [12] , in 2014, reported the enhanced performance of a PCM-modified plaster exhibiting specific heat capacity of 1.6 kJ/(kg K) against 0.77 kJ/(kg K) observed in the reference plaster. The integration of PCMs in lightweight building components was investigated by Fiorito [13] , employing EnergyPlus for simulating the use of PCMs in a naturally ventilated test room. In that study, higher benefits were obtained by adding PCMs in walls or partitions, linearly with PCM thickness. Lee and Medina [14] simulated a frame wall embodying hydrated salt (melting and solidification temperatures between 27.6 and 29.6 °C) macroencapsulated in containers larger than 1 mm. The aim was to reduce the cooling on-peak demand in California. Total energy saving reached values of 9.21 kWh/(m 2 ·year) due to PCM-enhanced frame walls. Energy saving between 30 and 55% in the HVAC system were registered by Navarro et al. [15] , who used an internal slab as a storage unit and as an active cooling supply in Spain. They used 52 kg of RT-21 paraffin macro-encapsulated in 1456 aluminium tubes of 12 mm diameter. Kenisarin and Mahkamov observed that further research activities on PCMs should, among the other objectives, achieve the narrowest possible temperature range for the phase change process in PCMs and reduce their costs [16] . Several research groups used paraffin, as reviewed by Zalba et al. [17] for its melting temperature (for instance, paraffin wax has a melting temperature of 28 °C) and its high latent heat (244 kJ/kg), highly compatible with uses in constructions.
Nanotechnologies can help enhancing PCMs performance, as a atural evolution, since abrupt changes may occur, at nanoscale
evel, in thermophysical and physicochemical properties. Then
ano-enhanced features of PCM materials could be suitably exloited and several research activities are currently working on his point, as reviewed by Parameshwaran and Kalaiselvam [18] . t has been observed that the inclusion of nanomaterials could mprove some PCMs figures of merit, overcoming some of their imitations, such as a low value of thermal conductivity [19] . To his aim, several nano-enhanced PCMs have been proposed, em-
odying, for instance, copper, titania, alumina, silica and zinc ox-
de nanoparticles (NPs), thoroughly investigated by Teng and Yu 20] : they showed that titania NPs are more effective than other dditives in order to enhance heat conduction and thermal storge capacity in paraffins, also affecting both melting onset tem-
erature and the solidification temperature. A completely differnt route to nano-enhancement of PCMs consists in their encapulation within a nano-shell [21] or a nanofiber [22] . In addiion, nano-shells protect PCMs from the surrounding environment. iu et al. [23] described the different routes to synthetize differnt kinds of nano-PCMs (sol-gel, miniemulsion, emulsion and in itu polymerization) and the respective advantages and disadvanages. Sari et al. [24] synthetized polystyrene and n-heptadecane
icro-/nanocapsules adopting the emulsion polymerization route ith capsule sizes ranging from 10 nm to 40 mm for a 1:2 ratio of
olystyrene and n-heptadecane. However, among different materils to be used for encapsulation, amorphous silica shows high heat torage capacity and thermal conductivity [25] . In addition, it is iocompatible, nontoxic for living organisms and the environment 26,27] , and in its core it is easy to confine active molecules acting s reservoir [28] . Zhang et al. [29] synthesized silica spheres (7– 6 μm) with n -octadecane core (melting temperature range of 23– 8 °C) using TEOS as an inorganic precursor by a sol-gel process, ith different steps. The obtained nanomaterials showed a good hermal conductibility. Similarly, Belessiotis et al. [30] obtained silca spheres with paraffin core via sol gel method showing a latent
eat of ∼ 156 kJ/kg. Latibari et al. [31] obtained nano-PCMs with almitic acid core and silica shell, using multistep sol-gel method nd investigated their thermal figures. The efficiency of encapsuation, defined as the percent ratio of the latent heat of the enapsulated PCM and that of the pure PCM, ranged from 83.25 to
9.55% (with a particle size between 183.7 and 722 nm) depending n pH of the chemical mix solution. Nevertheless, since palmitic
cid has a melting temperature of 61 °C, the application in buildngs is quite difficult. The same limitation (high melting temperaure ranging from 142.1 °C to 166.2 °C) concerned mannitol, chosen y Wu et al. [32] and Pethurajan et al. [33] .
The cost-effectiveness of PCMs inclusion in building envelopes as investigated by Kosny et al. [34] , who found that the commer-
ial cost of a PCM with a latent heat as high as 116 kJ/kg, while roduced commercially, can be projected to be 4.4–6.6 USD/kg. On he other hand, PCMs for building applications should be produced y means of environmental-friendly processes and raw materials.
mong the possible PCMs, paraffin is inflammable and it is classied as a doubtful carcinogen (source: Sigma-Aldrich), while PEG is n inert inexpensive and versatile polymer for customizing nanosructured materials due to its intrinsic biocompatibility and water olubility [35] . It is also widely used in the biomedical field and t has been approved by Food and Drug Administration for many pplications [36] . In addition, the range of melting temperature is etween 17 and 22 °C (Source: Sigma-Aldrich), that is well within he range of comfortable indoor environment temperatures and, or this reason, its application in buildings is preferable.

The SiO 2 @PEG600NP S howed a good thermal performance, with an enthalpy of fusion s high as 66.24 kJ/kg, in the tight melting temperature range 20–21 °C): such feature makes it a good candidate for thermal nergy storage in building applications, especially to reduce energy ses during winter season HVAC. As will be seen hereafter, it is recisely during the winter season that the incorporation of the CM inside the plaster performs its effectiveness. On the contrary, uring the summer season, it shows no particular benefit, mainly ecause the temperature of the internal surface of the vertical
alls is almost always above the T m of the PCM. Following the
xperimental design and synthesis activities of the nanostructures ncorporating PCMs, we performed dynamic simulations able to how the possible extent of energy savings obtained by integratng a certain percentage of SiO 2 @PEG600NP S (50%) in building ypsum plasters, comparing a reference case, devoid of PCM, with nother one, containing the proposed material applied over all nternal vertical plastered surfaces. It is the case to specify that he choice of PEG600 as a suitable PCM was carried out following
tight comparison aimed at identifying a material having, at the ame time, different specificities. Firstly, the compatibility with
low-cost synthesis mode of the hosting SiO 2 shell; secondly, t represented a biocompatible PCM and, finally, a series of preentive simulation activities (not reported in the text) provided n ideal range of melting temperatures to make the maximum ontribution during the winter season, associated to the maximum
enefit in terms of energy saving. After all these considerations nd activities, we decided to adopt the PEG600 as a material able o guarantee a satisfactory compromise.
. Materials and methods
In this experimental activity we have reported the results of a ross-disciplinary design and the full characterization of a novel anostructured material, showing the advantage of achieving full hape stabilization of a biocompatible PCM (PEG600) within the anoscale, inside a non-toxic amorphous SiO 2 shell. The main roperties of this specially designed material were fully characterzed after the chemical synthesis. To this aim, at first microscopy haracterization was carried out to observe shape and size of
anoparticles; then, thermal characterization was experienced in rder to know the main figures of merit describing PCMs beaviour. The last step was an in vitro toxicological assessment: this
ast characterization activity was carried out in order to learn if the
aterial presented significant toxicity and, therefore, risk profiles or human health. Data thus obtained were used as an input for he subsequent simulation activities.
.1. Synthesis and characterization of SiO 2 @PEG600
The synthesis was carried out adopting the so called Stöber ethod, following the procedure described in Stöber and Fink 37] with some modifications in order to encapsulate PCM S maerials. h at 25 °C (this temperature was optimal to maintain PEG600 n the liquid phase). Then, the reaction was blocked with aceone and the solution is centrifuged at 40 0 0 rpm for 20 min. The iO 2 @PEG600 NPs were rinsed with milliQ water and ethanol (1:1)
times and successively dried under reduced pressure and then at 00 °C for 2 h in order to obtain a white nano-powder. The yield or this synthesis was about 80%.

.2. Dynamic simulations in a case study
In order to test the potential benefits resulting from the use of he proposed PCM, a typical Italian dwelling, located in a multitorey building, was modelled in EnergyPlus ( Fig. 1 ). The overll floor surface is 78 m 2 and the internal height is 2.9 m. Its ast and West walls are shared with other apartments. The diiding walls are made of 20 cm thick tufa blocks, with plaster on oth faces (U = 0.622 W/m 2 K). Internal walls are made of 10 cm hick tufa blocks with plaster on both sides. Heat exchange takes place through the North and South walls, made of hollow clay blocks (30 cm thick), and through the west wall facing the stairway, which is also made of clay blocks (U = 0.736 W/m 2 K). Windows embody a 70 mm PVC frame (U f = 1.2 W/m 2 K) and a glazing system made of two 4 mm panes, divided by a 20 mm air gap (U g = 2.7 W/m 2 K). The values of global coefficient of heat exchange have been kept constant both in the reference case and in the model embodying PCMs within the internal plasters of vertical walls. This was done precisely in order to highlight the contribution of the PCMs on energy consumption for HVAC. Moreover, ceiling and internal floor did not include PCMs and the only non-adiabatic surfaces, therefore involved in the heat transmission mechanisms, were the vertical walls respectively exposed to North and South, as shown in Fig. 1 .
2.2.1. The energyplus model
A 3D model of the case study was first made in SketchUp using the OpenStudio plugin, and subsequently exported to EnergyPlus v. 8.8, a free simulation tool by the U.S. Department of Energy’s Building Technology Office, in order to perform the dynamic energy analysis. To assess the heating and cooling energy uses in a simplified way, an “IdealLoadAirSystem” with no outdoor air was considered. Adopting this approach, EnergyPlus provides heating and cooling energy required to meet the temperature at the selected setpoints (20.5 °C in winter, 26 °C in summer). This approach allows to calculate the thermal energy strictly necessary to achieve the comfort objectives represented by the temperature setpoints. In this way, we obtain the advantage of highlighting the free contribution of the material, neglecting the optimization effects of real HVAC systems.
However, in order to better simulate the actual transients that typically occur in real houses, the duty cycle of the heating thermostat was simulated by means of an Energy Management System so that the heating was turned off when air temperature was
bove T setpoint + 0.5 °C, while it was turned on when air temperaure fell below T setpoint –0.5 °C.
For ventilation, in order to simulate the actual opening cycles of indows in real conditions of use, the "Wind and Stack Open Area"
pproach was adopted in EnergyPlus, which allows to provide the ffective opening surface on the respective exposures. Windows having an open area of 0.4 m 2 for both Northern and Southern açades) were supposed to be open half an hour per day (from 7.30 o 8.00) during workdays, and one hour per day during weekends. n addition, for fixed openings and windows cracks (summing up o 0.03 m 2 area) an “always on” schedule was applied.
Simulations were carried out in three Italian cities belonging to ifferent climatic zones: Brindisi (climatic zone C, 1083 heating deree days), Rome (climatic zone D, 1415 heating degree days), and
ilan (climatic zone E, 2404 heating degree days). The heating chedule was adapted to each location, according to the climatic one they belonged to, depending on national regulations ( Fig. 2 ). he definition of such climatic zones is carried out according to the oncept of heating degree day, i.e. the sum of the daily thermal exursions extended to the winter heating period. The latter period s established by regulations in force. According to the Italian stan-
ard, all municipalities with a number of degree days between 900 nd 1400 are in zone C; the range of values for the D climatic zone s between 1400 and 2100 and between 2100 and 3000 for the E limatic zone.
Thus, in Brindisi heating worked from November 15th to March 1st, with up to 8 h per day. In Rome heating worked from Novemer 1st to April 15th with a maximum of 10 h per day, and in
ilan from October 15th to April 15th with a maximum of 12 h
er day. Cooling was considered to be turned on from July 1st to ugust 31st in all the locations. Envelope thermal resistance was onsidered unvaried, although climate zones were significantly diferent.

.3. Toxicological assays
Human alveolar basal epithelial cells (A549, ATCC® CCL-185 TM ) ere maintained in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium suppleented with 10% FBS, 50 μM glutamine, supplemented 100 U/mL enicillin and 100 mg/mL streptomycin. Cells were incubated in
humidified controlled atmosphere with a 95% to 5% ratio of ir/CO 2 , at 37 °C. For viability assay, A549 cells were seeded in 96 ell microplates (Constar) at concentration of 5 10 3 cells/well afer 24 h of stabilization. The SiO 2 @PEG600 NPs were added in orer to obtain a final concentration of 10 μg/mL and 40 μg/mL. The xposure was conducted for 24 h, 48 h, 72 h 96 h and the viability f cells expressed as percentage of living cells respect to control
as performed using the WST-8 assay (Sigma-Aldrich) following he procedure described previously [38] . For confocal acquisitions,
549 cells were incubated with NPs at different time points fol-
owing the procedure described in Ref. [39] . All confocal images
ere acquired using LSM700 (Zeiss, Germany) confocal microscope ounted on an Axio Observer Z1 (Zeiss, Germany) inverted mi-
roscope, by using the Alpha Plan-Apochromat (Zeiss) 100 x oilmmersion with 1.46 NA.
. Results and discussion
.1. PCM properties
SiO 2 @PEG600 nano-particles were firstly characterized in water y TEM in order to analyze their morphology, showing that NPs ere spherical and monodispersed with a size of (300 ± 15) nm Fig. 3 a). DLS measurements confirmed the size of NPs ( Fig. 3 b) howing a uniform size distribution. SEM-EDS analysis confirmed he morphology and smooth surface of NPs and further corroboated the presence of confined PCM (PEG600) in the SiO 2 NPs core. ndeed, the silicon, oxygen and carbon element peaks appeared in he graph (silicon and oxygen for silica and carbon and oxygen or PEG600) ( Fig. 3 c,d). FT-IR analysis was conducted on the NPs amples in order to verify the presence of bonds corresponding to
EG600 and SiO 2 .
Fig. 3 e showed a broad band in the region of ∼3375 cm −1 that orresponds to -OH stretching vibration. The vibrational bands oberved at ∼2917 cm −1 and ∼2849 cm −1 , related to the stretchng of –CH. The peak obtained at ∼1633 cm −1 was assigned to he stretching of -OH band while the peak at ∼1403 cm −1 was atributed to the vibration of -CH. The very strong and broad IR band t ∼1111 cm −1 , with a shoulder at ∼1188 cm −1 represented the Si-Si asymmetric stretching vibrations. The IR band at ∼800 cm −1 nd 956 cm −1 can be assigned to symmetric stretching vibrations f Si-O-Si and silanol groups respectively. The peak at ∼474 cm −1 as due to O-Si-O bending vibrations.
Thermal performance of novel SiO 2 @PEG600 was studied usng a Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) testing, providing the hermogram showed in Fig. 4 . The melting temperature (Tm) of the iO 2 @PEG600 NPs was found to be 21 °C, with a smooth transition tarting from about 10 °C, which was similar to that of the pure EG600 as described in a previous work [40] . .2. Energy saving potentials
The heating energy consumption per unit area was calculated, n an annual basis, using the results of the simulation process. This ctivity was carried out with reference to three different climatic ontexts, as mentioned previously (Brindisi, Rome, Milan). strong dependence on climatic conditions appeared. In fact, in rindisi savings were 4.3%, in Rome they reduced to 2.3%, and in
ilan they dropped to 1.6%. Such climatic dependence is strongly elated to the different profile of outdoor temperatures and radiaion patterns which finally influence the rate interior surfaces get older. A comparison of the absolute values of yearly energy de-

. Conclusions
The nano-encapsulation of a PCM for potential use in the contruction sector was investigated in this paper. In particular, in orer to enhance the potential of the PCM to contribute to energy aving and thermo-regulation of the indoor temperature in buildngs PEG600 was chosen because its melting temperature is close o 20 °C. In addition, in order to embody this material in plasters nd other building mixtures, the PCM was nano-encapsulated in a ilica shell which may also contribute to enhance mechanical proprties. The resulting product was analyzed under different points of iew.
Better results were obtained compared to commercial microenapsulated PCMs due to the increased specific surface of silica anoparticles, resulting in an increase of heat transfer and due o the reduced thickness of silica shells, hosting higher amounts f PCM active material in the nanoparticles core. metadata.abstractText: The paper presents the results of an experimental activity aimed at producing and characterizing a nanoencapsulated PEG600 (PCMs) into a silica shell. The nano-encapsulation was meant to be useful to improve the material’s suitability to integration in building components. The (300 ± 15) nm nanoparticles that were produced underwent a full characterization of their thermal performances. An enthalpy of fusion as high as 66.24 kJ/kg, in a tight melting temperature range (20–21 °C) was obtained, making the material suitable for thermal energy storage in buildings. In order to demonstrate the benefits of such as this technology on the reduction of heating and cooling demand of buildings, a concentration of 50% in weight of nanoparticles was, then, embedded into a gypsum plasterboard and used for all indoor plastered surfaces of a reference residential buildings. A saving of respectively up to 4.3% and up to 1.1% of heating and cooling energy demand was predicted in comparison to the ones of a building without PCM. Finally, the material underwent a full toxicological characterization exposing human alveolar basal epithelial cells to nanoparticles. The results showed that there were no toxic effects on cell morphology. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
